definition:
A continuous surjection $f$ on a topological space $X$ to itself is
*topologically transitive* if for every pair of open sets $U$ and $V$ in
$X$ there is an integer $n>0$ such that $f^n(U)\cap V\neq \emptyset$,
where $f^n$ denotes the $n$-th iterate of $f$.

If for every pair of open sets $U$ and $V$ there is an integer $N$ such
that $f^n(U)\cap V\neq \emptyset$ for each $n>N$, we say that $f$ is
*topologically mixing*.

If $X$ is a compact metric space, then $f$ is topologically transitive
if and only if there exists a point $x\in X$ with a dense orbit, i.e.
such that $\mathcal{O}(x,f)=\{f^n(x): n\in {\mathbb{N}}\}$ is dense in
$X$.
